text: [non-english speech]

MATTHEW CHANCE: This
is what's happening
on the streets of Chechnya.

A lawless Russian republic,
where gay men are allegedly
being abducted and tortured.

CNN obtained this cell phone
video from one victim, who
told us of horrifying abuse.

- They tied wires to my
hands, and put metal clippers
on my ears to electrocute me.

When they shock you, you
jump high above the ground.

MATTHEW CHANCE:
Chechen authorities

denied gay men, like those
we met, even exist there.

Now the Russian reporter who
first exposed the gay crackdown
is also living in fear.

Forced into hiding, amid,
terrifying death threats.

ELENA MILASHINA: This
is the first time
when they got that threat.

The kind of threat
when 15,000 of people

got together in the mosque,
and announced actual

jihad on all the staff
of Novaya Gazeta.

And it will last forever
till the last of one dies.

MATTHEW CHANCE: The threats made
by Muslim clerics in Chechnya,

were rebroadcast on
local television.

Religious leaders
are shown addressing

thousands of
faithful, condemning
the reports of a gay crackdown.
- [non-english speech]

MATTHEW CHANCE:
They're demanding

retribution against
those spreading what
they call, "gossip" and "lies".

It's a threat
journalists in Russia,

particularly at Novaya
Gazeta, take seriously.

In 2006, their star Chechnia
reporter Anna Politkovskaya,
was shot dead in Moscow.

The desk is still
kept as a shrine.

But since 2000, at least
five other journalists

at this same newspaper
have also been
killed in mafia style hits.

A sign of how dangerous
reporting in Russia

can be, and how brave our
reporters like Milashina,
to continue, despite the risks.

ELENA MILASHINA: The only way
that can stop the people who

might possibly think of
murdering my colleagues,

is to show them that
they will be another one.

MATTHEW CHANCE: And you're
prepared to put your life
on the line for the ordeal?
ELENA MILASHINA: Absolutely.

That makes me much stronger
than my enemies in, Chechnya.

MATTHEW CHANCE:
Strength to defend

the persecuted there, in the
face of the gravest threats.
Matthew Chance, CNN, Moscow.
